trial_identification.studytitle: Does an education program for caregivers at a stage 3 dementia care facility improve the quality of life for the residents, thereby reducing the use of antipsychotic medications for behavioural symptoms of dementia?
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In persons with moderate to severe dementia in stage 3 dementia care, does the person-centred approach of staff education and support, compared to the use of antipsychotics, reduce behavioural and psychological symptoms of dementia and reduce antipsychotic use?

conditions.healthcondition: Behavioural and Psychological Symptoms of Dementia

interventions.interventions:
EDUCATION:
All members of staff at the facility will attend a half day training session. The education will be provided by nursing staff from our team. It will cover what dementia is, how it affects the persons brain. How this translates to behaviours and how care staff can react to these behaviours, We will focus on Tom Kitwoods model of recognising the person behind the symptoms and use the Behavioural Staging Model to help staff recognise the different stages that people with dementia go through, with a corresponding change in our approach at a given stage. There will be a focus on being aware of responding to clients needs as they arise with a shift away from 'care by the clock' We will present our individual assessment tool and guide designed for the project so that staff are guided through the Antecedent-Behaviour-Consequences (ABC) approach of functional analysis.
SUPPORT & GUIDANCE: Once a week, for 2-3 hours a member of our team will attend the facility to review the behavioural assessment tools completed in that week. They will assist in the process of learning to problem solve why events occurred and which strategies might reduce these events occurring again. This will be carried out for 2 months. Outcome measures at 3 and 6 months.
interventions.comparator: Number of reported adverse incidents, observations from dementia care mapping, use of regular and 'as needed' antipsychotic use and use of neuropsychiatric inventory (NPI) before and after education program in the same patients. The patients therefore serve as their own controls.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Use of antipsychotics. We will review the use of regular and number of 'as needed' antipsychotics used for one month before the intervention then again at 3 and 6 months to determine a change in prescribing practice.
Incident reports of aggression. We will review the number of incident reports logged before and after the intervention

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: at 3 and 6 months and re-audit at one year

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Moderate to severe dementia in patients at a particular stage 3 rest home

trial_design.concealment: All patients will be subject to the intervention so there is no allocation concealment
trial_design.designfeatures: Patients serve as their own controls. There is no need for a washout period as the patients will not be taking any medications as an intervention.
trial_design.statisticalmethods: We are seeking statistical support from Chris Frampton at Otago University. Our sample size is one of pragmatic convenience, i.e. all those consenting at the one site. the study aims to establish some initial signal of acceptance and feasibility of our suggested education programme, as well as effectiveness albeit to a lesser degree.
